Photothermal catalytic methane dry reforming (DRM) technology can convert greenhouse gases (i.e. CH4 and CO2) into syngas (i.e. H2 and CO), providing more opportunities for reducing the greenhouse effect and achieving carbon neutrality. In the DRM field, Ni-based catalysts attract wide attention due to their low cost and high activity. However, the carbon deposition over Ni-based catalysts always leads to rapid deactivation, which is still a main challenge. To improve the long-term stability of Ni-based catalysts, this work proposes a carbon-atom-diffusion strategy under photothermal conditions and investigates its effect on a Zn-doped Ni-based photothermal catalyst (Ni3Zn@CeO2). The photothermal catalytic behavior of Ni3Zn@CeO2 can maintain more than 70 h in DRM reaction. And the photocatalytic DRM activity of Ni3Zn@CeO2 is 1.2 times higher than thermal catalytic activity. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation and experimental characterizations indicate that Ni3Zn promotes the diffusion of carbon atoms into the Ni3Zn to form the Ni3ZnC0.7 phase with body-centered cubic (bcc) structure, thus inhibiting carbon deposition. Further, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy and DFT calculation prove Ni3Zn@CeO2 benefits the CH4 activation and inhibits the carbon deposition during the DRM process. Through inducing carbon atoms diffusion within the Ni3Zn lattice, this work provides a straightforward and feasible strategy for achieving efficient photothermal catalytic DRM and even other CH4 conversion implementations with long-term stability. Graphical Abstract This work proposes a straightforward and feasible strategy for diffusing carbon atoms into the Ni3Zn lattice, thereby enhancing the stability of Ni-based catalysts for photothermal catalytic dry reforming of methane (DRM). Keywords Photothermal catalysis Methane dry reforming Ni-based catalyst Stability enhancement Carbon atom diffusion 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM) technology achieves a conversion from CH4 and CO2 into syngas (H2 and CO) and is expected to simultaneously solve the issue of the greenhouse effect and provide alternative energy fuels [ 1–3 ]. Thus, DRM technology attracted tremendous attention in both chemistry and catalysis communities [ 4–6 ]. However, both CH4 and CO2 are very stable and inert molecules due to their symmetrical molecular configuration, meaning high temperatures (~800 °C) are usually required for the activation of C–H and C=O bonds during the conventional thermal catalytic DRM process [ 7 ]. In the last decades, various innovative means have been developed for driving DRM reactions under mild conditions. In particular, photothermal catalytic DRM technology with light energy assistance attracts special attention because it overcomes the thermodynamic energy barrier and realizes a highly efficient CH4 conversion under mild conditions [ 8,9 ]. Therefore, it is hoped that the photothermal catalytic DRM system contributes to energy conversion and even carbon neutrality. Among different photothermal catalytic platforms, Ni-based catalysts are especially attractive because of their low price and excellent catalytic activity so that they have been widely used and studied in DRM reactions [ 10,11 ]. Nonetheless, a strong cracking process of CH4 molecules (CH4 → C* + 4H*) inevitably occurs on the Ni surface. The C* species tend to accumulate on the Ni surface, forming stable carbon deposition and eventually leading to the deactivation of Ni-based catalysts. Therefore, removing/inhibiting carbon deposition over Ni-based catalysts has a significant meaning in promoting the large-scale industrialization of photothermal catalytic DRM implementation. A rational way to eliminate carbon deposition over catalysts under mild conditions is by means of tailoring the location of carbon atoms into interstitial sites of nickel units. In this case, the electronic/geometric properties of interstitial carbon atoms are tuned so that the subsurface carbon atoms will take part in catalytic reaction cycles instead of being a poisoning agent. Consequently, this carbon atoms transfer mechanism is believed to play a critical role in boosting catalyst stability during various catalytic implementations (e.g., photothermal catalytic DRM reactions) [ 12 ]. Although very promising from a theoretical point of view, overcoming the inherent physicochemical limitations of Ni units is still a great challenge for introducing carbon atoms into Ni lattices. Besides, it has been reported that the interstitial atoms can directly participate in reactions with the surface-adsorbed reactants, leading to novel reaction pathways [ 13 ]. So the DRM reaction mechanism might be affected due to the presence of the interstitial carbon atoms. Accordingly, the aforementioned strategy for removing carbon deposition still requires further investigation to prove its feasibility in photothermal catalytic DRM systems and clarify the potential effects in reaction pathways. Motivated by the potential ability of the above strategy towards improving catalyst long-term stability, herein, an alloyed Ni3Zn loaded CeO2 (Ni3Zn@CeO2) photothermal catalyst is designed and fabricated. The design of the Ni3Zn alloy phase is due to a consideration that the introduction of external metal atoms can effectively tune the Ni lattice parameter so as to achieve readily inclusion and diffusion of atoms at interstitial sites especially under light irradiation [ 14,15 ]. As a proof-of-principle, the as-prepared Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst is exploited for photothermal catalytic DRM application. Compared to traditional thermal catalytic conditions, Ni3Zn@CeO2 displays an obvious improvement in photothermal catalytic activity with 349.9 and 509.1 μmol·g−1·min−1 of H2 and CO evolution rates, respectively. The mechanism studies suggest the improved activity resulted from the photothermal effect, enhanced CO2 absorption ability, and improved reduction ability of Ni3Zn@CeO2. More importantly, compared to a single Ni-loaded catalyst (Ni@CeO2), Ni3Zn@CeO2 displays excellent stability after 70 h of long-term DRM measurement. The XRD analysis confirms the stability enhancement should be attributed to the increased spatial radius of Ni3Zn, benefiting the diffusion of the carbon atom to the body center of the Ni3Zn octahedron and thereby the in-situ formation of the Ni3ZnC0.7 phase, which is displayed by the advanced DFT calculation. Further, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFT) and DFT calculation reveal that the first step of CH4 activation could complete more rapidly over Ni3Zn@CeO2 than Ni@CeO2, ensuring the high activity of Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst. Meanwhile, the final step of CH4 cracking, which mainly leads to carbon deposition, could be inhibited by the carbon-atom-diffusion mechanism. Consequently, this work provides a reliable strategy for developing Ni-based catalysts with excellent stability via a carbon-atom-diffusion mechanism. Through architecting alloy phase nanoparticles, this stability enhancement mechanism is easy to expand into other photothermal platforms and reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ni3Zn@CeO2 was prepared by a coprecipitation method. In detail, 2.23 g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), 2.04 g of cerous nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O), and 0.51 g of zinc nitrate hydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O) were dissolved in 80 mL of distilled water to form a homogeneous solution A. Two portions of 3.01 g of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were dissolved in two portions of 80 mL of distilled water respectively, and solutions B and C were obtained, respectively. Solution A and solution B were dripped simultaneously into solution C under the continuous stirring condition. Afterwards, the mixture was kept at 40 °C for 5 h. The product was collected by centrifugation and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. Then, the product was transferred to a muffle furnace and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain NiO-ZnO-CeO2. Finally, NiO-ZnO-CeO2 was reduced at 500 °C for 140 min under 10% H2/N2 atmosphere to obtain the Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst. For comparison, Ni@CeO2 was also prepared via the same method but without using zinc nitrate hydrate. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Various characterization methods were used to evaluate the physicochemical properties and reaction mechanism of catalysts. The morphological images of samples were recorded using a JEM-2800 transmission electron microscope (TEM). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained from a Rigaku Ultima IV X-Pert diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA. The optical properties of samples were examined and recorded using a UV-visible spectrophotometer (Integrating Sphere). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha photoelectron spectrometer with an Al Ka ray Oiv = 1486.6 eV as the excitation source, and the catalyst was calibrated with C 1s = 284.8 eV. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was used to evaluate the thermal stability of samples and the carbon deposits on spent catalysts. The TGA tests of samples were performed on a STA6000/8000 simultaneous thermal analyzer at the temperature range from 50 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 in an air atmosphere. The H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on Micromeritics AutoChem 2930 chemisorption analyzer with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) detector. Before the experiment, about 0.1 g of catalyst powder was weighed and purged with N2 gas at 500 °C for 30 min, then cooled to 50 °C and switched to 10% H2/N2 mixed gas as the reducing gas at a flow rate of 30 mL·min−1. The temperature was raised to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 and held for 10 min when the instrument baseline was stable. All the desorbed molecules were detected by a TCD. The CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was performed on the same instrument as H2-TPR. 0.1 g of the catalyst was purged with helium gas, heated from room temperature to 300 °C (10 °C·min−1), and maintained at this temperature for 1 h. Then, the temperature was cooled to 50 °C, and the gas was switched to a mixture of CO2/He (30 mL·min−1, 10 vol% CO2 in He), and maintained for 1 h until the CO2 adsorption reached saturation. Then, He gas was purged for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed CO2 from the surface. Finally, the temperature was increased from 50 °C to 900 °C (10 °C·min−1) in a He atmosphere. The amount of CO2 desorbed during this process was detected using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In-situ DRIFTS was carried out on a Bruker infrared spectrometer (Tensor II) equipped with a liquid nitrogen-cooled mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector in a three-window diffuse-reflectance cell (Harrick) with a nonmodified dome cover. Two IR measurement windows were made of ZnSe, while the SiO2 window was used for light irradiation. The resolution was 4 cm−1. The IR scanning range was 4000–900 cm−1 averaging over 100 scans. The gas composition and flow rate were consistent with the catalytic tests, 0.1 g of catalyst, with visible light irradiation (300 W Xe lamp). In the atmosphere of pure N₂ at room temperature for 30 min, the background was subtracted three times. Then, the reaction gas (CO2:CH4 = 5:5 mL·min−1) was turned on and heated from 50 to 500 °C at an interval of 35 °C, and the spectrograms at each temperature were collected. 2.3 Photothermal catalytic DRM performance evaluation The photothermal catalytic performance evaluation was conducted in a normal-pressure photothermal reactor. Firstly, 0.1 g of the as-prepared sample was placed in the flat area of the vertical quartz tube in the reactor, and the temperature was heated to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1. Then, a 300-watt xenon lamp was turned on to irradiate the sample, and reactants CH4:CO2 = 1:1 were introduced. The total flow rate was 10 mL·min−1, and the reaction space velocity was 6000 mL·g−1·h−1. The reactants and products were detected and analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a TCD detector, with an analysis performed each 30 min. The flow rate of the effluent gas was measured with a flow meter. The CO2 and CH4 conversion rates were calculated according to the following equations [ 16 ]: CH 4 , ( cov - rate ) = F in ( CH 4 ) × CH 4 , cov V m × m cat CO 2 , ( cov - rate ) = F in ( CO 2 ) × CO 2 , cov V m × m cat CH 4 , cov = F in ( CH 4 ) - F out ( CH 4 ) F in ( CH 4 ) × 100 % CO 2 , cov = F in ( CO 2 ) - F out ( CO 2 ) F in ( CO 2 ) × 100 % where CH4, (cov-rate), CO2, (cov-rate), CH4, cov, CO2, cov, F in, F out, V m, and m cat were the conversion rate, the conversion, the molar flow rate of CO2 and CH4 in the reactor inlet and outlet, the volume flow rate of the gas and the catalyst mass, respectively. 2.4 DFT calculation All DFT calculations were carried out by the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). In order to elucidate the coordination condition of carbon atoms in Ni3Zn phase and compare the free energy of CH4 dissociation over Ni and Ni3ZnC0.7, firstly, the binding energy of two possible coordination structures was simulated by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation function [ 17 ]. During the structure optimization process, the convergence criterion of total energy was set to 10−4 eV, and the atoms were relaxed until the force acting on each atom was lower than 5 × 10−2 eV·Å−1 [ 18,19 ]. The kinetic energy cutoff of the plane-wave was set to be 400 eV. The Brillouin zone was sampled with Monkhorst-Pack meshes of 3 × 3 × 1 grid [ 20,21 ]. After obtaining the coordination structure between carbon atoms and Ni3Zn, the as-calculated theoretical model was utilized to further evaluate the energy barrier (Gibbs Free Energy) during CH4 dissociation [ 22 ]. In detail, the CH4 molecules were placed near the surface of Ni with face-centered cubic (fcc) structure or Ni3ZnC0.7, in which C was fixed in body center of Ni3Zn crystal, respectively. Then, the Gibbs Free Energy during CH4 activation steps (CH4 → CH3 + H* → CH2 + H* → CH + H* → C + H*) could be calculated in VASP software [ 19,22 ]. 2.5 A purging experiment on the Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR catalyst with periodically using CO2 or CH4 (1) The Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR catalyst after the photothermal catalytic DRM reaction was characterized by XRD. (2) The catalyst was placed into the reactor and heated up to 500 °C. Under the irradiation of a 300W xenon lamp (simulating the DRM reaction conditions), CO2 (5 mL·min−1) was introduced to purge for 60 min. (3) XRD characterization was performed again. (4) With the same conditions, the catalyst was purged by CH4 for 60 minutes. (5) XRD characterization analysis was carried out again. (6) The catalyst was purged by CO2 and analyzed by XRD characterization. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The preparation process of Ni-based photothermal catalysts follows two stages (see Section 2.1): (1) firstly, NiO-CeO2 and NiO-ZnO-CeO2 catalysts were prepared via a coprecipitation method with corresponding nitrates as the precursors. (2) NiO-CeO2 and NiO-ZnO-CeO2 were reduced at 500 °C for 140 min under 10% H2/N2 atmosphere to obtain Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2, respectively. Before evaluating the photothermal catalytic DRM performance, the fundamental properties of the Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts were characterized as shown below. The crystalline structures of Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts were characterized by XRD (Fig. 1(a) ). In Ni@CeO2 catalyst, the characteristic peaks detected centered at 28.5°, 33.0°, 47.4°, and 56.3° could be assigned to the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS No. 43-1002). In addition to the CeO2, two diffraction peaks at 44.5° and 51.8° could be attributed to the (111) and (200) facets of metallic Ni, respectively [ 23 ]. In the XRD pattern of Ni3Zn@CeO2, the aforementioned peaks of Ni shifted from 44.5° and 51.8° to 43.7° and 50.9°, respectively, suggesting the expanded lattice spacing and the formation of Ni3Zn crystal phase [ 14 ]. The XRD results showed the successful synthesis of Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts. Moreover, the radius of the octahedral (R oct) site in face-centered cubic metals can be calculated by following the equation R oct = 0.414 R M, where R M represents the metallic radius of metal atom [ 24 ]. The lattice parameter of Ni increased from 3.562 to 3.582 Å due to the formation of the Ni3Zn structure. The radius of the octahedral space of Ni is expanded from 0.517 to 0.524 Å. The structure and elemental distribution of the Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst were characterized by HR-TEM and STEM images with energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) mapping. The exposed lattice distance of the crystallites was 2.06 Å corresponding to the (111) plane of Ni3Zn (Fig. 1(b)) [ 25 ]. STEM with EDS mapping of Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts showed a uniform distribution of the Ni and Zn on the CeO2 support (Fig. 1(c)). These results confirm that the Ni3Zn intermetallic structure was successfully synthesized in the reduction step without forming separate single element particles. It further indicates that we have successfully doped Zn into the lattice of Ni. 3.2 Photothermal catalytic activity Once confirming the successful preparation of Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts, the photothermal catalytic DRM experiments were conducted over Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2. The DRM reactions were performed at 500 °C in a fixed-bed reactor. The reactants (CO2 and CH4) and products (H2 and CO) were quantitatively analyzed every 30 min by GC with a TCD detector. During the thermal catalytic DRM reaction, the initial CH4 and CO2 conversion rates of Ni@CeO2 were 468.9 and 446.4 μmol·g−1·min−1, respectively (Figs. 2(a) and (b) ). Under light illumination, the photothermal catalytic DRM efficiency of Ni@CeO2 was improved with 599.4 and 575.8 μmol·g−1·min−1 of CH4 and CO2 conversion rates. The results exhibited the enhancement effect of light irradiation, which might induce a photothermal effect over metallic nanoparticles (NPs) so as to improve DRM efficiency as previously reported [ 8 ]. However, the activity of the Ni@CeO2 catalyst decreased rapidly within 2 h, since the serious carbon deposition from the strong cracking reaction of CH4 on monometallic Ni blocked reactor pipeline [ 26–28 ], inhibiting the continuous reaction. Therefore, the long-term stability of Ni-based catalysts should be further studied and improved as follows. Regarding the Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst, under thermal-driven reaction conditions, Ni3Zn@CeO2 exhibited initial CH4 and CO2 conversion rates of 465.2 and 470.2 μmol·g−1·min−1, corresponding to H2 and CO yield rates of 275.2 and 399.2 μmol·g−1·min−1, respectively. With the assistance of visible light, the photothermal catalytic activity of Ni3Zn@CeO2 (536.5 and 543.4 μmol·g−1·min−1 for initial CH4 and CO2 conversion rates, respectively) was approximately 1.2 times higher than that of the thermal reaction. And the initial evolution rates of H2 and CO on Ni3Zn@CeO2 were 349.9 and 509.1 μmol·g−1·min−1, separately (Fig. S1). The results indicated that the alloyed Ni3Zn could effectively increase the DRM activity of Ni-based photothermal catalysts. To further elucidate the effect of Ni3Zn NPs, more characterizations were conducted in the following sections. 3.3 Enhancement effect of Ni3Zn NPs in DRM reaction Firstly, the UV-vis spectra were obtained on Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 to investigate their optical properties (Fig. 3(a) ). Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 showed the absorption edges at ~420 nm, corresponding to the typical band edges of pristine CeO2 with 2.32 eV bandgaps. Besides, the existence of Ni or Ni3Zn NPs enhanced the light absorption ability, especially in the visible-near infrared light range (420–800 nm). In consideration of the high light-thermal energy conversion ability of visible and near-infrared light, the strong optical properties would lead to high temperature, which could be considered as a photo-assisted thermal effect (one of the photothermal effects). The photothermal effect could accelerate the reactant activation so that the activity could be increased under light illumination as mentioned before [ 8 ]. Secondly, the metal-support interaction (MSI) of Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 were studied by H2-TPR measurement (Fig. 3(b)). Notably, during this measurement, NiO-CeO2 and Ni3ZnO-CeO2, which were respectively the precursor of Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2, were utilized to observe the transformation of NiO and Ni3ZnO to metallic Ni and alloyed Ni3Zn phase and thus clarify their MSI properties. The H2-TPR result of NiO-CeO2 showed four deconvolution peaks at 160, 195, 340, and 400 °C, suggesting the reduction of NiO to metallic free Ni, α, β, and γ-type Ni [ 29,30 ]. The Ni3ZnO-CeO2 showed similar four peaks at 190, 250, 440, and 500 °C. Additionally, another peak at 598 °C could be deconvoluted owing to the formation of the Ni3Zn phase. Generally, the peaks shift to higher temperatures suggested stronger metal-support interaction (i.e. between Ni3Zn and CeO2). The highest temperature of the Ni3Zn peak suggested the strongest reducibility compared to other Ni species. Finally, considering that CO2 adsorption could affect the subsequent activation and reaction steps (Fig. 3(c)), the CO2-TPD measurements were conducted on Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst to study the CO2 adsorption behavior. Ni@CeO2 exhibited three characteristic peaks at 100–600 °C. The peak at 100–250 °C was attributed to the interaction between CO2 and weak Brønsted OH groups [ 31,32 ]. The shoulder peak that emerged at 240 °C could be from the weak adsorption of CO2 by the active component Ni [ 33,34 ]. The peak at ~380 °C could be assigned to the formation of bidentate carbonates on metal-oxygen pairs. Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst had similar CO2 adsorption peaks, but the shoulder peak at 240 °C had higher intensity, indicating that Ni3Zn enhanced the weak adsorption of CO2, which was beneficial for the subsequent DRM process [ 35 ]. The improvement of CO2 weak adsorption might be the result of the increased spatial radius of the Ni octahedron as discussed in XRD results [ 14 ]. Another peak at 450–500 °C could be observed on Ni3Zn@CeO2, indicating the formation of Ni3Zn with strong basic sites at the interface of CeO2 [ 36 ]. The strong basic sites always led to Lewis basic sites, which led to a large amount of strongly adsorbed CO2 being adsorbed at the interface. Therefore, the Lewis basic sites on Ni3Zn@CeO2 adsorbed a large amount of adsorbed CO2, which will be transferred to the active sites and undergo the reverse Boudouard reaction (CO2 + C → 2CO) with the carbon generated by methane cracking. This promoted the generation of CO and avoided carbon deposition. 3.4 Long-term stability of Ni3Zn@CeO2 As mentioned before, the long-term stability of Ni@CeO2 should be improved, thereby, the stability of Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst towards DRM application was evaluated (Fig. 4 ). The long-term photothermal catalytic stability test was conducted on the Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst. Specifically, the catalyst exhibited a low deactivation rate of 0.13% h−1 for CH4 and 0.17% h−1 for CO2 under light irradiation. After 70 h of reaction, CH4 and CO2 conversion rates of Ni3Zn@CeO2 remained stable without noticeable deactivation. The thermal catalytic stability was also evaluated, showing more decline in reactants conversion rates compared to photothermal catalytic stability. A comparison table summarized the advantage of Ni3Zn@CeO2 in the DRM stability (Table S1). Therefore, the results confirmed the as-designed Ni3Zn@CeO2 effectively enhanced the long-term stability during photothermal catalytic DRM reactions. In order to clarify the stability enhancement mechanism, more characterizations and theoretical calculations were performed as follows. 3.5 Carbon deposition and coordination between C and Ni3Zn@CeO2 Firstly, the variation of the main phase in Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst after the photothermal (denoted as Ni@CeO2-AR and Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR) and thermal (denoted as Ni@CeO2-AR-T and Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR-T) DRM reaction was studied by XRD analysis (Fig. 5(a) and Fig. S2). Compared to Ni@CeO2 before DRM reaction, the positions of Ni diffraction peaks of Ni@CeO2-AR and Ni@CeO2-AR-T had no clear changes, but the peak intensity increased, which might be due to the weak interaction between Ni NPs and CeO2 leading to the aggregation of Ni NPs during DRM reaction. In contrast, after thermal or photothermal reaction, the characteristic peaks of Ni3Zn shifted to a lower degree according to the XRD patterns of Ni3Zn@CeO2, Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR and Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR-T. The peak changes suggested the further expanded lattice spacing of Ni3Zn. And the shifted peaks were in accordance with the XRD diffraction peak of the Ni3ZnC0.7 crystal phase (JCPDS No. 28-0713). These results confirmed a carbon-atom-diffusion process on the Ni3Zn@CeO2 surface as our design. More direct evidence was provided by TEM images (Figs. 5 (b)–(e) and Fig. S3). After 2 h photothermal and thermal DRM reaction, a lot of filamentous carbon was formed on Ni@CeO2-AR and Ni@CeO2-AR-T compared to fresh Ni@CeO2 catalyst. Thus, the carbon deposition should be the main reason for the poor long-term stability of Ni@CeO2 and rapid reactor pipe blockage. However, no serious agglomeration or carbon deposition was observed on Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR and Ni@CeO2-AR-T after 70 h DRM reaction. Considering that the deposition of carbon might exist in the form of small particles on the surface of the Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR catalyst and was difficult to distinguish in TEM images, Raman spectroscopy was further employed to analyze the carbon deposition on the surface of the catalyst after the reaction (Fig. S4). To ensure reliability, the Raman spectra were obtained from three different sites on the Ni@CeO2-AR catalyst after the (photo)thermal catalytic DRM reaction. After both thermal and photothermal catalytic DRM experiments, in the Ni@CeO2-AR Raman spectra (Fig. S4(a) and (b)), D and G peaks at 1350 and 1580 cm–1, respectively, could be detected, indicating the general carbon deposition issues on the un-modified Ni@CeO2 catalyst. On the contrary, the characteristic peaks from carbon did not appear in the Raman spectra of the Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR catalyst (Figs. S4(c) and (d)). Indeed, according to Raman results, the resistance ability towards carbon deposition was improved on Ni3Zn@CeO2. The HR-TEM of Ni3Zn@CeO2 showed the lattice spacing of the (111) crystal plane expanded from 2.06 Å of Ni3Zn0.74 to 2.11 Å of Ni3ZnC. And STEM with EDS mapping characterization displayed a similar distribution of Ni, Zn, and C elements. These results further proved the in-situ formation of Ni3ZnC0.7 phase in Ni3Zn@CeO2 after DRM reaction. The difference between Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 in carbon deposition states should be attributed to the different C subsidence energy barriers on the Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts. In detail, the C species (C*) from CH4 cracking had a higher subsidence energy barrier on the Ni@CeO2 catalyst, leading to continuous accumulation on the Ni surface and eventually covering the active sites. The C* with a lower subsidence energy barrier on the Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst would deposit on the subsurface of Ni3Zn to form Ni3ZnC0.7, ensuring that Ni3Zn active sites could be exposed to reactant atmosphere to maintain the high activity of the catalyst. To further investigate the conversion pathway of carbon atoms during the photothermal catalytic DRM reaction process, with XRD analysis, a purging experiment on the Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR catalyst periodically using CO2 or CH4 was performed (Fig. S5) After purging with CO2 for 60 minutes, the XRD diffraction peaks of the Ni3ZnC0.7 component in the Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR catalyst all shifted to the diffraction peaks of Ni3Zn. It indicates that carbon atoms in Ni3Zn could react with CO2 so that the Ni3ZnC0.7 phase transferred back to the Ni3Zn phase. However, when using CH4 for the purging operation, Ni3Zn was converted into Ni3ZnC0.7, the same as the main phase after DRM reactions. This should be attributed to the CH4 cracking, leading to the re-addition of carbon atoms into the Ni3Zn lattice. But, when CH4 was replaced by CO2, the purging process turned Ni3ZnC0.7 to Ni3Zn again. Therefore, through the periodic purging process, the results confirmed the reversible transformation between Ni3Zn and Ni3ZnC0.7 structure, suggesting the carbon atoms should directly take part in the whole reaction process. In this case, the carbon deposition was significantly inhibited, and the long-term stability of the Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst was realized. To quantitatively analyze the deposited carbon, TGA measurements were performed on the Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts after the DRM reaction (Fig. 5(h) and Fig. S6). From Fig. 5(h), when the temperature was lower than 200 °C, the mass decline (1.4 wt%) was ascribed to the removal of adsorbed water. The mass increase of Ni@CeO2-AR at 150–360 °C might be attributed to the oxidation of Ni NPs. The mass loss of Ni@CeO2-AR catalyst at 400–600 °C (8.1 wt%) was due to the combustion of the graphitic carbon. Thus, the graphitic carbon was the main deposited carbon state and should be responsible for the deactivation of Ni-based catalysts (i.e. Ni@CeO2). Regarding the Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR-T catalyst, a 2.6 wt% mass reduction occurred within the temperature range of 360–600 °C. In contrast, for the Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR, the mass decreased within the same temperature interval was merely 1.4 wt%. This indicated that there is less harmful carbon deposition on the surface of the Ni3Zn@CeO2. Moreover, light irradiation could further enhance the anti-coking property of the catalyst and suppress the activity decline. This was due to the photothermal effect resulting from the strong light absorption capability of Ni3Zn@CeO2, leading to a higher diffusion and elimination rate of C within Ni3Zn and more stable activity as exhibited in stability test. XPS analysis was performed to characterize the elemental states of Ni and C in Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts. In the Ni 2p spectrum of the Ni@CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 5(i)), the peak of Ni2+ at 854.8 eV was attributed to the inevitable surface oxidation. The peak of Ni0 was located at 851.8 eV. In the XPS spectrum of Ni3Zn, the peak of Ni0 shifted to the lower binding energy (851.3 eV) due to the electron coupling in Ni3Zn alloy and the strong MSI effect between Ni3Zn and CeO2. Generally, the electrons shifted to Ni species could enhance the alkalinity, contributing to CO2 adsorption and thus benefiting the whole DRM process. After DRM experiments, the Ni 2p spectrum of Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR was also obtained to investigate the changes in the Ni3Zn phase. The characteristic peak of Ni x+ species belonging to Ni3Zn shifted to a higher binding energy value, which should be attributed to the formation of Ni3ZnC0.7 causing the electron transfer from Ni x+ to C*, resulting in a decline in the electron density of Ni x+. The Ni x+ with low electron density could inhibit the strong cracking reaction of CH₄ (CH* = C* + H*), consistent with the previous literature [ 37 ]. The elemental states of deposited carbon and coordination condition between C and Ni3Zn were further studied according to the XPS spectra of C 1s in catalysts before and after photothermal and thermal catalytic reactions (Fig. S7). In comparison of Ni@CeO2 and Ni@CeO2-AR, besides the three typical peaks of C 1s at 284.8, 286.4, and 289.0 eV corresponding to C–C, C–O, and C=O, respectively, there was a new peak at 284.0 eV in Ni@CeO2-AR and Ni@CeO2-AR-T. This peak should be from the carbon deposition on the Ni@CeO2 surface after the DRM reaction. On the contrary, the C 1s XPS spectra of Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR and Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR-T had almost the same characteristic peak as that of Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst. No peak from carbon deposition could be detected on the Ni3Zn@CeO2-AR. Consequently, the XPS results confirmed not only the formation and electron structure of Ni3ZnC0.7 but also the strong resistance ability of Ni3Zn@CeO2 towards carbon deposition because of the carbon-atom-diffusion mechanism. The coordination structure of Ni3ZnC0.7 was displayed through DFT calculation. To propose the Ni3ZnC0.7 crystal structure, firstly, the Ni3Zn alloy model was constructed according to the atom ratio and the lattice distance extracted from XRD results. X Ni atoms and y Zn atoms were distributed at the vertex of the cubic crystalline, which was based on metallic Ni as the main phase. Considering the atom radius size and the free space in the Ni3Zn lattice, two possible structures of Ni3ZnC0.7 were proposed (Fig. 5(j)), in which the carbon atoms were located at body or face centers. According to their binding energy, when carbon atoms were located at the body center of Ni3Zn (i.e. body-center cubic structure), the binding energy was lower than that of face-center cubic (fcc) structure. Therefore, carbon atoms could easily diffuse into Ni3Zn to form Ni3ZnC0.7 with a body-center cubic (bcc) structure and be thermodynamically metastable during the DRM process. 3.6 Reaction pathway of DRM over Ni3Zn@CeO2 During the DRM experiments, it should be noticed that the ratio between CO and H2 in the syngas product was higher than 1, suggesting that the conversion pathway towards CO evolution might be different between Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2. According to the above results, Ni3ZnC0.7 with metastable carbon atoms might have an impact on the DRM reaction pathway. To verify this idea, the CH4 and CO2 conversion routes were real-time monitored via in-situ DRIFTS analysis, which could detect the intermediates under photothermal catalytic DRM conditions. The in-situ DRIFT measurements were conducted on Ni@CeO2 and Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalysts in CH4/CO2 atmosphere with a temperature-program equipment. When Ni@CeO2 was exposed to CO2 and CH4, several peaks could be detected with temperature increasing (Fig. S8 and Table S2). In detail, the peaks centered at 3016 and 1306 cm−1 belonged to gaseous CH4. The peak at 1350 cm−1 was from CH3* species owing to the CH4 dissociation on the Ni surface. When the temperature was 500 °C, the CH3* peak almost disappeared, suggesting it was further dissociated. Thus, on the Ni@CeO2 catalyst, the CH4 cracking was serious and rapid, resulting in the C* species not participating in the DRM process and efficiently removed on the Ni surface at a lower temperature (i.e. 500 °C). The C* species would link orderly through the C=C bonds, thus forming a lot of filamentous carbon covering the surface of Ni as displayed in the TEM image. Eventually, the low reactivity of deposited carbon inhibited the subsequent DRM cycles and even caused the blockage of the reactor vessel. The broad peak centered at 2250–2400 cm−1 was identified as gaseous CO2. Two intermediates from CO2 activation could be detected at 1405 and 1570 cm−1 belonging to the monodentate carbonates (m-CO2*) and bidentate carbonates (b-CO2*), respectively. It can be found that the peak intensity of COOH* detected at 1603 cm−1 increases as the peak of b-CO2* decreases. It indicates that b-CO2* tended to react with H* generated by methane cracking to form COOH*. With the temperature rising, COOH* was converted into CO* and OH* as displayed in DRIFT spectra. In the in-situ DRIFT spectra of Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 6(a) ), similar peaks from CH4 and CO2 activation and reaction could also be detected. However, the CH3* species could be maintained on Ni3Zn@CeO2 surface, meaning that Ni3Zn effectively inhibited the cracking of CH4 so as to avoid carbon deposition on the surface. On the other hand, the peak intensity of b-CO2* decreased rapidly on Ni3Zn@CeO2 with the increase in temperature, and completely disappeared when the reaction temperature was 500 °C. And the COOH* could not be observed on Ni3Zn@CeO2 during the measurement, indicating a direct conversion route and faster conversion rate of b-CO2* to generate CO on Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst, leading to the higher ratio of CO in syngas product. According to the above results, the DRM reaction pathways including CH4 and CO2 conversion routes on the Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst were proposed: (1) CH4 would be gradually dissociated on the Ni3Zn surface to produce H* and C*. However, during this step, because the spatial radius of the alloyed Ni3Zn was larger than Ni, the energy barrier for C* on the Ni3Zn surface was low enough to sink to the Ni3Zn subsurface, leading to the formation of Ni3ZnC0.7 phase. (2) CO2 was activated to b-CO2* on Ni3Zn@CeO2. Meanwhile, the XPS results demonstrated the electron transfer from Ni x+ to C* so that carbon atoms as interstitial atoms in Ni3ZnC0.7 were under thermodynamically metastable state [ 38–40 ] and were likely to react with b-CO2* species even at low temperatures [ 12,41 ]. Obviously, the CO2 conversion route was simplified without COOH* intermediate. More importantly, the interaction between diffused carbon atoms in Ni3ZnC0.7 and b-CO2* species was an elimination pathway of diffused carbon atoms (C* → Ni3ZnC0.7* → CO*) and ensured that the new C atom could be continuously diffused into Ni3Zn phase after several DRM reaction cycles. This contributed to the excellent long-term stability of Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst in the photothermal catalytic DRM system. Once again, the DFT calculation was utilized to theoretically clarify the advantages of Ni3Zn in the DRM reaction by studying the energy barrier of interaction between Ni3Zn with metastable carbon atoms (i.e. Ni3ZnC0.7) and CH4 (Fig. 6(b)). The Ni3ZnC0.7 model was from the previous DFT results. The results exhibited that compared to Ni NPs, the energy barrier of the first three steps of CH4 dissociation (CH3* → CH2* + H* → CH* + H*) on Ni3ZnC0.7 was lower, suggesting that Ni3Zn was beneficial for the conversion of CH4 into CH3* and the rapid formation of Ni3ZnC0.7. However, the last CH4 activation steps (CH* → C* + H*) need more activating energy on Ni3ZnC0.7 than Ni NPs because of the lower electron density of Ni x+, consistent with the XPS analysis result. Hence, from the theoretical view, DFT results confirmed Ni3ZnC0.7 could promote the first three steps of CH4 activation and restrict too much C* within a short time, avoiding too much carbon deposition on Ni3Zn active sites and enhancing long-term stability during DRM reaction. 4 Conclusions In this work, a feasible strategy has been proposed for enhancing the long-term stability of Ni-based photothermal catalysts during the DRM process. An alloyed Ni3Zn-loaded CeO2 was fabricated via a straightforward impregnation method and a repeatable reduction process under the H2/N2 atmosphere. As a proof-of-principle, the as-designed Ni3Zn@CeO2 was used as a model catalyst for investigating the photothermal catalytic DRM activity and stability. The results showed an optimal catalytic activity of Ni3Zn@CeO2 with 349.9 and 509.1 μmol·g−1·min−1 of H2 and CO evolution rates, respectively. The improvement should be attributed to the strong light absorption ability inducing a photothermal effect, CO2 absorption capacity, and high reduction ability, which are proved by a series of systematical characterizations. Further, Ni3Zn@CeO2 exhibited excellent stability during long-term 70 h DRM reactions. The mechanism studies confirmed that carbon deposition was inhibited. Carbon atoms from CH4 dissociation tended to coordinate with Ni3Zn unit cells, avoiding the deactivation of Ni3Zn@CeO2 catalyst and leading to Ni3ZnC0.7 with bcc structure and thermodynamic metastable interstitial carbon atoms proved by advanced DFT calculation. Finally, in-situ DRIFT comprehensively clarified the DRM reaction route including CH4 and CO2 conversion, during which the coordinated carbon atoms could interact with b-CO2* intermediates to result in a complete diffusion-reaction cycle of carbon atoms. Moreover, under light irradiation, this carbon atoms diffusion-reaction cycle process will be further promoted via photothermal effect. DFT calculation displayed the advantages of the carbon-atom-diffusion strategy in promoting DRM reaction and avoiding carbon deposition through forming the Ni3ZnC0.7 phase. Therefore, this study proved the great ability of the carbon-atom-diffusion mechanism towards improving the stability of Ni-based catalysts. It is expected that this strategy could be further exploited in other catalytic systems beyond Ni-based catalysts and DRM application, contributing to the industrialization of photothermal catalysis technology. coredata.dc:description: Photothermal catalytic methane dry reforming (DRM) technology can convert greenhouse gases (i.e. CH4 and CO2) into syngas (i.e. H2 and CO), providing more opportunities for reducing the greenhouse effect and achieving carbon neutrality. In the DRM field, Ni-based catalysts attract wide attention due to their low cost and high activity. However, the carbon deposition over Ni-based catalysts always leads to rapid deactivation, which is still a main challenge. To improve the long-term stability of Ni-based catalysts, this work proposes a carbon-atom-diffusion strategy under photothermal conditions and investigates its effect on a Zn-doped Ni-based photothermal catalyst (Ni3Zn@CeO2). The photothermal catalytic behavior of Ni3Zn@CeO2 can maintain more than 70 h in DRM reaction. And the photocatalytic DRM activity of Ni3Zn@CeO2 is 1.2 times higher than thermal catalytic activity. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation and experimental characterizations indicate that Ni3Zn promotes the diffusion of carbon atoms into the Ni3Zn to form the Ni3ZnC0.7 phase with body-centered cubic (bcc) structure, thus inhibiting carbon deposition. Further, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy and DFT calculation prove Ni3Zn@CeO2 benefits the CH4 activation and inhibits the carbon deposition during the DRM process. Through inducing carbon atoms diffusion within the Ni3Zn lattice, this work provides a straightforward and feasible strategy for achieving efficient photothermal catalytic DRM and even other CH4 conversion implementations with long-term stability.
